awd_abstract_narration:
NRT-DESE:  Interdisciplinary Disease Ecology Across Scales: from Byte to Benchtop to Biosphere

Infectious diseases are an ongoing threat to human health, animal health, and social stability. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) project prepares doctoral students at the University of Georgia with data-enabled science and engineering training to solve complex, interdisciplinary problems related to diseases and the environment. Effectively predicting where new infectious agents will go next, how fast they will spread, and how severely humans or other species may be impacted requires a basic knowledge of how hosts and pathogens interact at different scales of biological organization (e.g., cell, organism, population), as well as the ability to identify how processes taking place at one scale respond to or affect processes occurring at adjacent scales. This traineeship anticipates preparing thirty (30) doctoral students, including twenty (20) funded trainees, with mastery of both empirical and computational dimensions of contemporary infectious disease problems. 

Research activities associated with the program focus on three topical areas critical to unraveling the complexity of host-pathogen interactions in nature: co-infection and pathogen interactions; environmental change and disease dynamics; and tipping points and early warning signals. Faculty from thirteen academic units with empirical expertise spanning single cells to whole ecosystems, and quantitative expertise in statistical modeling, mathematical modeling, stochastic processes, adaptive dynamics, machine learning, and geographic mapping will co-mentor student research. This traineeship will use interdisciplinary case study-based teaching, instruction in advanced techniques for computer modeling, and internships at non-academic and international organizations to provide students with the conceptual background, computational skills, and global perspective needed to tackle the most pressing infectious disease problems of our time. In addition, a range of professional development activities including a capstone experience, data clinics, internships, study abroad, and communication training will provide students with the skills to transfer basic knowledge to real world problems in both academic and non-academic settings. 

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new, potentially transformative, and scalable models for STEM graduate education training.  The Traineeship Track is dedicated to effective training of STEM graduate students in high priority interdisciplinary research areas, through the comprehensive traineeship model that is innovative, evidence-based, and aligned with changing workforce and research needs.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: The central goal of the Interdisciplinary Disease Ecology Across Scales (IDEAS) program was to train PhD students at the University of Georgia (UGA) in new ways to solve infectious disease problems occurring at the interface of different scales of biological organization. To achieve this goal, the IDEAS curriculum was designed to produce trainees with: (i) the conceptual expertise to identify problems that bridge multiple levels of biological organization and to frame research questions at the intersections and boundaries of these levels; (ii) advanced computational skills that can be applied to developing and implementing research that spans levels of organization; and (iii) a global perspective whose skills can transfer to non-academic sectors where infectious disease research is translated into practical application (e.g. business, government agencies, non-governmental organizations). During the 6-year program period, 37 students were recruited into the program across five cohorts (2016-2020). These students were mentored by 26 faculty from 15 different academic units across the UGA campus. To date, trainees have published 40 journal articles and book chapters, 95% of which address questions involving more than one biological scale of organization. Over 60% of these publications use advanced computational tools and at least half focus on multi-national problems. In addition to their academic research activities, IDEAS trainees also engaged in hands-on internships that spanned industry, government, and academic sectors. Specifically, of 10 completed or ongoing internships, four were in government, four in industry and two were academic. Moreover, two of three IDEAS trainees who graduated from the program with a PhD were hired by their internship organization, highlighting the effectiveness of the program at producing trainees with skills that help solve real-world problems.

 Broader impacts: In terms of broader impacts, the IDEAS program has had three major impacts. First, IDEAS has contributed to building a more diverse STEM student population at UGA, particularly in the thematic area of infectious diseases where a diversity of perspectives and approaches is crucial for advancing innovation. Of 37 trainees recruited into the program, 11/37 (30%) were underrepresented minorities and 7/37 (20%) were Asian, for a total of 50% non-majority student enrollment. Second, IDEAS introduced a new paradigm for integrative graduate training at UGA. Importantly, the programming developed by IDEAS had a major impact beyond IDEAS trainees, with >350 non-IDEAS students, postdocs, research staff, and faculty at UGA benefitting from IDEAS courses, computational workshops, and communications training. Third, IDEAS is also poised to have an impact beyond UGA. Content from the IDEAS curriculum, including a module from the flagship 'Fundamentals of Disease Biology' course which takes a cross-scale approach to infectious disease training, and introductory elements of the program's computational training, have been developed as online resources that are freely available to other students, researchers, and the general public.
